title: ‘Thursday Murder Club,’ Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: The book adaptation of the mystery series comes to Netflix, and Peacock airs the “Love Island USA” reunion.
content:
Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are airing or streaming this week, Aug. 25-31. Details and times are subject to change.

On Aug. 29, 2005, Hurricane Katrina made landfall on the Gulf Coast, leading to breaches in New Orleans flood prevention; 80 percent of the city was submerged in water. The cost of the damage from the hurricane was $125 billion, and though it’s been difficult to get an accurate death toll, it is estimated to be about 1,800.

In 2006, Spike Lee directed the documentary “When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts,” which detailed, straight from mouths of New Orleans residents, the preparation, crisis and aftermath, and now he is back as an executive producer of a new three-part series “Katrina: Come Hell and High Water.” In his first documentary, many residents were still in the throes of the tragedy, but now Lee is giving people a chance to reflect on the past 20 years. Lee directed one of the episodes — Geeta Gandbhir and Samantha Knowles directed the others. Streaming Wednesday on Netflix.
summary: The following year's anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, the anniversary of the disaster, is August 25th. The cost of the storm is estimated to be $100 million. The documentary "When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts" was released in 2006 and is now being produced by Spike Lee, an executive producer of the series "Spective", which focuses on the preparation, crisis and aftermath of the event. The series will be shown on PBS.
shortSummary: The aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath are marked by diverse TV events, including:
argos_summary: The article lists TV shows and specials airing Aug. 25‑31, then discusses Hurricane Katrina’s 2005 impact and the $125 billion damage. It highlights Spike Lee’s 2006 documentary “When the Levees Broke” and his new three‑part series “Katrina: Come Hell and High Water,” which reflects on the past 20 years. Lee directed one episode, while Geeta Gandbhir and Samantha Knowles directed the others, and the series streams on Netflix.
